<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MARKETS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/25/spac-boom-rolls-2021?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Another SPACtacular Year
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Lady Gaga gushing praise" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=530 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/TjGFDxbbZRYjv9vpCL/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Lady Gaga gushing praise" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/TjGFDxbbZRYjv9vpCL/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) were undoubtedly the Silly Bandz of 2020. In total, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/19/business/dealbook/deals-mergers-acquisitions-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">242 SPACs</a> were launched last year, accounting for nearly half the money raised via public offerings.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The SPAC club includes billionaire investors like Bill Ackman and Chamath Palihapitiya, former House Speaker Paul Ryan, and even Shaq.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Unlike Silly Bandz, SPACs may have some staying power. So far in 2021, an average of five new SPACs has been launched every business day, attracting nearly $20 billion from investors. That already exceeds 2019’s total.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Let’s SPAC up for a minute</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like the word “erudite,” SPAC might be a term that you hear frequently without fully understanding what it means. A SPAC is a publicly traded shell company whose single purpose in life is to merge with another company, taking them public in the process. Investors buy shares in the “blank-check” company, trusting the people behind the SPAC to identify a promising target to acquire. SPACs typically have two years to secure a deal before they are contractually obligated to return any money raised to investors. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Some notable companies that went public via SPACs are DraftKings, Virgin Galactic, and essentially the entire electric vehicle industry—26 companies tied to mobility and technology went public via SPAC last year, with </span><span><a href="https://insideevs.com/news/481681/list-ev-spac-completed-upcoming/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">five more</a></span><span> already on the docket for 2021. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So why SPAC?</strong> For one, they’re quicker than a traditional IPO process. Hims, a telehealth startup, negotiated with SPAC Oaktree Acquisition Corp. for just four months before agreeing to a deal that would take it public. A traditional IPO would have taken 12 to 18 months, the company’s CEO <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/when-spacs-attack-a-new-force-is-invading-wall-street-11611378007?mod=hp_lead_pos3&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told the WSJ</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Wall Street sees icebergs ahead </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Goldman Sachs was the third most active underwriter of SPAC IPOs last year, but CEO David Solomon said in last week’s earnings call that they “need to be pulled back or rebalanced in some way.” His main concern? SPACs have become <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-01-20/why-goldman-sachs-boss-is-right-about-spac-mania?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">way overhyped</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">One example:</strong></span><span> The SPAC SoftBank launched last year is currently trading 34% higher than its initial price...but it hasn’t even announced an acquisition target.  </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>down the road SPACs may be less popular than they are now, replaced by other creative ways to go public. We're clearly not close to that point yet.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/24/wuhan-marks-one-year-since-coronavirus-lockdown-began?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Wuhan Lockdown: 1 Year Later
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="WUHAN, CHINA - FEBRUARY 03:  (CHINA OUT) An aerial view of the roads and..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODI1L2RhaWx5X2xpZmVfaW5fd3VoYW5fZHVyaW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Stringer/Getty Images. Wuhan on February 3rd.</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, the Chinese city of Wuhan marked the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/22/world/asia/wuhan-china-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first anniversary</a> of its infamous “lockdown,” when 11 million people were simultaneously put into strict quarantine to stop the coronavirus from spreading across the country. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The lockdown lasted 76 days, from late January until April. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At the time, the world was stunned that a government would enforce such harsh restrictions on the movement of people and the ability of businesses to operate. Little did we know that Lockdown Lite was coming to countries and cities around the world in the subsequent months. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So what’s it like in Wuhan now? The Chinese have largely managed to stamp out Covid-19, so life is almost “normal.” But a recent uptick in new cases in other regions of China has muffled local business activity, <a href="https://www.npr.org/transcripts/957916986?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">according to NPR</a>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>China was the only major economy to grow last year. It’s recorded fewer than <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-55628488?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">100,000 coronavirus cases</a> and about 4,800 deaths in total (some experts question these numbers). </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the upcoming Lunar New Year will put China’s Covid response to the test. About 200 million people are expected to travel in what’s referred to as humanity’s largest annual migration. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
AUDIO
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/25/clubhouse-reportedly-valued-1-billion-latest-round-funding?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Talk Is No Longer Cheap
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Clubhouse, the audio-based social media platform, confirmed it closed another round of funding led by Andreessen Horowitz over the weekend. The valuation wasn’t disclosed, but a few days before, The Information reported investors were eyeing a <a href="https://www.theinformation.com/articles/clubhouse-gets-investment-interest-at-1-billion-valuation?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$1 billion</a> price tag, 10x higher than Clubhouse’s previous round.  </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The app, which allows users to join virtual rooms to eavesdrop on other people’s conversations (it’s not as creepy as it sounds), has managed to attract 2 million users, including stars like John Mayer, Oprah Winfrey, and Meek Mill, since launching back in April 2020. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While Clubhouse has been successful in building a diverse user base that spans from tech to hip-hop, it hasn’t yet given its creators the option to monetize their followings. The latest round of funding will go toward developing a <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2021/01/24/clubhouse-announces-plans-for-creator-payments-and-raises-new-funding-led-by-andreessen-horowitz/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">creators fund</a> aimed at supporting the app’s most popular users. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Creator funds are becoming a staple of platforms trying to attract and hold onto talent. TikTok launched a $200 million fund to compensate creators last year, while Snapchat has also been handing out <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/style/snapchat-spotlight.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">millions of dollars</a> a week to attract people to its TikTok-esque video platform, Spotlight. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/24/larry-king-dies-87?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Larry Says Listen
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Larry King" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODIzL2xhcnJ5X2tpbmcuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Rodin Eckenroth/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The iconic TV host Larry King died on Saturday at 87. Having racked up more than 30,000 interviews during his TV and radio career, he gained a lot of wisdom. Here's one of our favorite Larry lessons:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">"I remind myself every morning: Nothing I say this day will teach me anything. So if I'm going to learn, I must do it by listening. I never learned anything while I was talking."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ For more Larry: </strong>Here are some <a href="https://variety.com/2021/tv/news/larry-king-dead-87-celebrity-interviews-1234890790/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">legendary moments</a>. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/24/week-ahead-davos-sundance-move-online?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Week Ahead: Ski Town Sadness
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="A general view taken on January 25, 2018 shows the town of Davos, easter..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODI2L3N3aXR6ZXJsYW5kLWRhdm9zLXBvbGl0aWMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Miguel Medina/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quiet Davos: </strong>The annual World Economic Forum summit, which had been scheduled to start today, is moving from the Swiss Alps to cyberspace. World leaders including Chinese President Xi Jinping and German Chancellor Angela Merkel will call for global cooperation to address the pandemic.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Busy earnings: </strong>It’s going to feel like the first weekend of March Madness over the next few days, with more than 20% of S&P companies releasing their financial stats from last quarter. The No. 1 seeds are Apple, Facebook, Microsoft, and Tesla. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Economic check-up: </strong>On Thursday, we’ll get a first look at fourth-quarter GDP, which is projected to have increased 4.7%. That would mean the economy shrank by 3.5% in 2020. The Fed also meets this Wednesday, but it’s not expected to make any drastic announcements. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else:</strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Senate will vote on Janet Yellen’s confirmation as Treasury secretary today.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The 2021 MLB Hall of Fame class will be announced on Tuesday. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Sundance Film Festival (smaller schedule, more virtual) begins Thursday.</span></li>
</ul>

The US has been averaging 1.16 million doses a day over the past week—at this rate, we can hit the Biden administration’s goal of 100 million shots in the new president’s first 100 days.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eMarkets: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs earnings season hits its crescendo, the major US equities indexes are at or near all-time highs. href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/01/25/spac-boom-rolls-2021?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nAnother SPACtacular Year\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Lady Gaga gushing praise\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=530 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/TjGFDxbbZRYjv9vpCL/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Lady Gaga gushing praise\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/TjGFDxbbZRYjv9vpCL/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSpecial purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) were undoubtedly the Silly Bandz of 2020. In total, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/19/business/dealbook/deals-mergers-acquisitions-2020.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e242 SPACs\u003c/a\u003e were launched last year, accounting for nearly half the money raised via public offerings.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe SPAC club includes billionaire investors like Bill Ackman and Chamath Palihapitiya, former House Speaker Paul Ryan, and even Shaq.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUnlike Silly Bandz, SPACs may have some staying power. So far in 2021, an average of five new SPACs has been launched every business day, attracting nearly $20 billion from investors. That already exceeds 2019’s total.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLet’s SPAC up for a minute\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLike the word “erudite,” SPAC might be a term that you hear frequently without fully understanding what it means. A SPAC is a publicly traded shell company whose single purpose in life is to merge with another company, taking them public in the process. Investors buy shares in the “blank-check” company, trusting the people behind the SPAC to identify a promising target to acquire. SPACs typically have two years to secure a deal before they are contractually obligated to return any money raised to investors. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSome notable companies that went public via SPACs are DraftKings, Virgin Galactic, and essentially the entire electric vehicle industry—26 companies tied to mobility and technology went public via SPAC last year, with \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://insideevs.com/news/481681/list-ev-spac-completed-upcoming/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efive more\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e already on the docket for 2021. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eSo why SPAC?\u003c/strong\u003e For one, they’re quicker than a traditional IPO process. Hims, a telehealth startup, negotiated with SPAC Oaktree Acquisition Corp. for just four months before agreeing to a deal that would take it public. A traditional IPO would have taken 12 to 18 months, the company’s CEO \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/when-spacs-attack-a-new-force-is-invading-wall-street-11611378007?mod=hp_lead_pos3\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold the WSJ\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWall Street sees icebergs ahead \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGoldman Sachs was the third most active underwriter of SPAC IPOs last year, but CEO David Solomon said in last week’s earnings call that they “need to be pulled back or rebalanced in some way.” His main concern? SPACs have become \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-01-20/why-goldman-sachs-boss-is-right-about-spac-mania?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eway overhyped\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne example:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e The SPAC SoftBank launched last year is currently trading 34% higher than its initial price...but it hasn’t even announced an acquisition target.  \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003edown the road SPACs may be less popular than they are now, replaced by other creative ways to go public. We're clearly not close to that point yet.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: Later\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"WUHAN, CHINA - FEBRUARY 03:  (CHINA OUT) An aerial view of the roads src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zODI1L2RhaWx5X2xpZmVfaW5fd3VoYW5fZHVyaW4uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eStringer/Getty Images. Wuhan on February 3rd.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday, the Chinese city of Wuhan marked the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/22/world/asia/wuhan-china-coronavirus.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst anniversary\u003c/a\u003e of its infamous “lockdown,” when 11 million people were simultaneously put into strict quarantine to stop the coronavirus from spreading across the country. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe lockdown lasted 76 days, from late January until April. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt the time, the world was stunned that a government would enforce such harsh restrictions on the movement of people and the ability of businesses to operate. Little did we know that Lockdown Lite was coming to countries and cities around the world in the subsequent months. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo what’s it like in Wuhan now? The Chinese have largely managed to stamp out Covid-19, so life is almost “normal.” But a recent uptick in new cases in other regions of China has muffled local business activity, \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/transcripts/957916986?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccording to NPR\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eChina was the only major economy to grow last year. It’s recorded fewer than \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-55628488?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e100,000 coronavirus cases\u003c/a\u003e and about 4,800 deaths in total (some experts question these numbers). \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe upcoming Lunar New Year will put China’s Covid response to the test. About 200 million people are expected to travel in what’s referred to as humanity’s largest annual migration. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eClubhouse, the audio-based social media platform, confirmed it closed another round of funding led by Andreessen Horowitz over the weekend. The valuation wasn’t disclosed, but a few days before, The Information reported investors were eyeing a \u003ca href=\"https://www.theinformation.com/articles/clubhouse-gets-investment-interest-at-1-billion-valuation?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$1 billion\u003c/a\u003e price tag, 10x higher than Clubhouse’s previous round.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe app, which allows users to join virtual rooms to eavesdrop on other people’s conversations (it’s not as creepy as it sounds), has managed to attract 2 million users, including stars like John Mayer, Oprah Winfrey, and Meek Mill, since launching back in April 2020. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile Clubhouse has been successful in building a diverse user base that spans from tech to hip-hop, it hasn’t yet given its creators the option to monetize their followings. The latest round of funding will go toward developing a \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2021/01/24/clubhouse-announces-plans-for-creator-payments-and-raises-new-funding-led-by-andreessen-horowitz/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecreators fund\u003c/a\u003e aimed at supporting the app’s most popular users. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eCreator funds are becoming a staple of platforms trying to attract and hold onto talent. TikTok launched a $200 million fund to compensate creators last year, while Snapchat has also been handing out \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/15/style/snapchat-spotlight.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emillions of dollars\u003c/a\u003e a week to attract people to its TikTok-esque video platform, Spotlight. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
